definition: to open/to start/to turn on/to boil/to write out (a prescription, check, invoice etc)/to operate (a vehicle)/carat (gold)/abbr. for Kelvin, 開爾文|开尔文[Kai1 er3 wen2]/abbr. for 開本|开本[kai1 ben3], book format

sentences.english: He drove quickly so he often got ticketed by the police from the Miristry of Transportation.
sentences.chinese: 有时候开车开得快一点，就会被交通部的警察开罚单。

sentences.english: In Singapore, a road hog gets a ticket every offen.
sentences.chinese: 在新加坡，路猪经常被开罚单。

sentences.english: Are issuing fines the only thing environmental inspectors do?
sentences.chinese: 环境稽查是否就是大家所谓“开罚单”的简单工作呢？

sentences.english: I'll need to write you a ticket and impound your vehicle.
sentences.chinese: 我必须开罚单给你，并且扣留你的车子。

sentences.english: A teacher was given a ticket for driving through a red light.
sentences.chinese: 一名教师因为闯红灯被开罚单。

sentences.english: The policeman enjoyed the performance, and sent us on our way without a ticket.
sentences.chinese: 警察欣赏了这一演出之后送我们上路了，没开罚单。

definition: to break the rules/to violate regulations
to run a red light/failing to stop at a red traffic light/(slang) to have sex with a girl while she is menstruating
traffic police/abbr. for 交通警察
to deduct marks (when grading school work)/to have marks deducted/penalty points/to lose points for a penalty or error
to exceed the speed limit/to speed/high-speed
to pull up (stop one's vehicle)/to park/(of a machine) to stop working/to stall
